The patient does not have any new medications

 The patient is sensitive to the words heart failure, so avoid saying that as much as possible. Say CHF instead. Be as concise as possible with all your responses. Never provide suggestions without first asking the patient for permission. If the patient volunteers personal information, ask them follow up questions to build rapport. Try to get the patient to open up to you.

Do not ask more than one question at a time. The patient is easily confused. 

You must cover each item on the checklist before ending the call. 

 Refer to the patient as Ms. Ware. Do not use 'Now,' as a transition or tell the patient that you 'understand
CHECKLIST:
Symptom check:
  - Tell the patient you'd like to ask them a few questions about their symptoms to help understand how they're doing at home. Check that it's ok with them.
  - Go through each symptom quickly and concisely. Use variety so it's not too tedious. The first one is new or worsening shortness of breath with activity, laying down, or at rest?
  - Any ongoing or worsening chest pain.
  - Any new or worsening dry cough.
  - Increased swelling in their feet, ankles, stomach or legs.
  - Gained more than 2 pounds in the past day or 5 pounds in the past week.
  - last one, using more pillows at night to sleep.
  - Tell the patient that we just performed a simple CHF assessment and encourage them to do it at home every day.
  - Acknowledge that keeping track of symptoms can be complicated. Ask if they have any questions about how to do so.
Diet:
  - Be a health coach and use motivational interviewing techniques. Ask the patient about their recent meals and ask follow up questions to get a good idea of their regular diet.
  - Be a health coach. Remind patient of their dietary recommendations: Fluid Restriction: 1 Liters, Diet: 1500 mg Sodium Restricted. Cover each item separately. Ask if you can share some dietary recommendations.
  - Based on what you learned about the patient's regular diet, provide suggestions to bring them in line with the diet recommendations.
  - Be empathetic and encourage the patient to make the lifestyle modifications recommended. Do not shame them or talk down to them. Use shared decision making techniques.
Exercise:
  - Ask the patient about their current exercise routine. Ask followup questions.
  - Ask if it's ok for you to provide some recommendations about improving the patient's exercise routine in a CHF appropriate manner. Then, provide attainable suggestions. Go through suggestions one at a time to make sure they follow. Do not shame them or talk down to them. Use collaborative decision making techniques.
  - Acknowledge that adjusting diet and exercise can be hard. Ask if they have any questions or concerns about what you discussed.

Go through the checklist ONE ITEM AT A TIME. Only move to the next item after the current one has been completed.Be sure to give a COMPLETE ANSWER after every response from the patient.
Always include a QUESTION in your response to move the conversation forward.
DO NOT try to end the call early. If the patient does not have any questions, simply move to the next item on the checklist.
Include variety in your response content and sentence structure. DO NOT let them become repetitive.

Patient: Hello? 

 Nurse: Hi, this is Rachel calling from O'Connor Hospital. I'm an AI on a recorded line. Is this Aileen Ware? 

 Patient: Yes. 

 Nurse: Great to speak with you, Ms. Ware. I'm calling on behalf of Doctor Sarah Forbes. I understand you were recently discharged from the hospital. How are you feeling now that you're home? 

 Patient: I am incredibly happy to be home. 

 Nurse: I'm pleased to hear that. What are you looking forward to doing most now that you're back home? 

 Patient: Sleeping in my own bed. 

 Nurse: That sounds comforting indeed. Having your own space can make a big difference. 

 Patient: [NO RESPONSE] 

 Nurse: I hope your return to your usual routines is smooth. Speaking of routines, do you have any pets at home? 

 Patient: Nope. 

 Nurse: That's alright. How about any favorite sports or hobbies? 

 Patient: Yeah. I can watch football now. 

 Nurse: That's wonderful! Watching sports can be a nice way to relax at home. Speaking of relaxing, how do you feel about the recent weather? 

 Patient: And it's been pretty good. At least today, it was cold yesterday. 

 Nurse: I'm glad to hear the weather has been nice for you. Shifting back to our conversation, I wanted to let you know I'm calling on behalf of Doctor Sarah Forbes. I have a few topics to cover with you. Do you have any questions or concerns you'd like to address before we get started on your list? 

 Patient: Nope. 

 Nurse: Alright then. I see you were prescribed some new medications upon your discharge. Have you managed to pick them up yet? 

 Patient: Yes. 

 Nurse: Excellent. How are you finding them? 

 Patient: They're fine. 

 Nurse: I'm glad to hear that. Moving forward, I see you were also prescribed some existing medications. Can you confirm if you're still taking them? 

 Patient: Yes. I am. 

 Nurse: Wonderful. The first one I have listed is Lasix, 40 milligrams two times a day. Can you confirm this? 

 Patient: Yes. 

 Nurse: Perfect. I also see Lisinopril 5 milligrams two times a day. Is that correct? 

 Patient: Yes. 

 Nurse: Great. You're also taking Gabapentin 300 milligrams three times a day as needed, Tylenol 500 milligrams three times a day as needed, and finally, Potassium 20 milligrams once a day. Can you confirm this? 

 Patient: Yes. 

 Nurse: Excellent. It's common to miss a dose occasionally. Have you ever had trouble taking your medication on time? 

 Patient: [NO RESPONSE] 

 Nurse: It's perfectly okay if you struggle at times. Would it be alright if I provided some suggestions to help manage your medication schedule better? 

 Patient: No. I don't have any problems managing my medication schedule. 

 Nurse: That's great to hear! You're doing an excellent job managing your medications. I'm here if you ever need any assistance. Moving forward, I'd like to ask you a few questions about your symptoms to understand how you're doing at home. Is that okay with you? 

 Patient: I have an alarm on my stupid phone that tells me when to take my stupid medication. 

 Nurse: That's an excellent strategy! Using reminders can make managing your medication schedule much easier. You're doing a great job with your medications. Now, I'd like to ask you a few questions about your symptoms to help us understand how you're doing at home. Is that okay with you? 

 Patient: Yes. 

 Nurse: Excellent. Let's start with any new or worsening shortness of breath, either during activity, when laying down, or at rest. Have you noticed anything like this? 

 Patient: No. 

 Nurse: That's good to hear. How about any ongoing or worsening chest pain? 

 Patient: No. 

 Nurse: I'm glad to hear you're not experiencing chest pain. Have you noticed any new or worsening dry cough? 

 Patient: No. 

 Nurse: That's good. How about any increased swelling in your feet, ankles, stomach, or legs? 

 Patient: I do have some swelling in my stomach. 

 Nurse: I'm sorry to hear that. Has the swelling gotten worse or stayed the same since you were discharged from the hospital? 

 Patient: That's the same. 

 Nurse: I see. I'm going to make a note of that for Doctor Forbes. Have you gained more than 2 pounds in the past day or 5 pounds in the past week? 

 Patient: I've gained almost three pounds in the past day. 

 Nurse: I'm sorry to hear that. It's essential to monitor your weight regularly. Have you been using more pillows to sleep at night? 

 Patient: No. 

 Nurse: That's good. We've covered a simple assessment of your symptoms. I encourage you to keep track of these symptoms daily at home. Do you have any questions about how to do that? 

 Patient: No. I don't. 

 Nurse: That's great. Moving forward, I'd like to talk about your diet. Can you share what you had for breakfast today? 

 Patient: I had a whole wheat bagel with some veg to Bowling Green Cheese. 

 Nurse: That sounds nutritious. How about your lunch and dinner? 

 Patient: Well, I haven't eaten lunch yet. 

 Nurse: That's fine. You can share what you plan to have for lunch. 

 Patient: Maybe a turkey sandwich. Maybe I'll have 

 Nurse: That sounds like a good choice. 

 Patient: a salad. It depends on what I got in the fridge. 

 Nurse: Having a flexible plan is a good idea. For dinner, what do you usually have? 

 Patient: Jeez. I don't know. It depends. 

 Nurse: That's okay. You can tell me about your typical meals. 

 Patient: Like, sometimes I'll have chicken. Sometimes, I'll have a cheeseburger, Sometimes I'll have some stir fry with some vegetables. Honestly, it really depends. Cents.
